context.speaker: Kannon K. Shanmugam
context.text: It's a distinction that the model penal code itself described as important. And that is simply the distinction between an action that is intended to cause harm and an action that is not intended to cause harm but merely involves a substantial risk of it. And that is the distinction that we think that the language of the force clause captures. But I would make one additional point that I have not made to date, and that is that even if you think that the "against" phrase doesn't do all of the work, I would submit that this Court's decisions, and particularly its decision in Begay, do the remainder of the work because they make clear that the relevant language must be understood in its statutory context, which is to provide a definition of the phrase "violent felony." And where someone acts recklessly, even though the law obviously attributes to that person a substantial degree of moral culpability, that action simply doesn't fall within the ordinary meaning of "violent felony." And the second point I would make, Justice Breyer, is that whatever you might think about sort of the fine gradations in particular hypotheticals, I would respectfully submit that it would be a lot harder to draw the line between recklessness and criminal negligence because negligence itself in the model penal code is defined as being a -- a -- a situation in which an actor should be aware of, once again, a substantial and unjustifiable risk. As the government recognizes in Footnote 5 of its brief, states often define criminal negligence in recklessness terms.

context.speaker: Kannon K. Shanmugam

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas

context.speaker: Eric J. Feigin

It seems to me our precedent in the labor organizing context has drawn the lines and has established a very narrow and very simple resolution for this case, and I want you to tell me why it's wrong or why you disagree with it. Babcock was obviously a statutory case but informed by the Constitution explicitly, as I read it, and the question was how much access will we allow to property under the statute, the NLRA, given the constitutional backdrop of property rights? And the decision seems to reflect the Court's understanding of the Constitution and how much protection there is for property rights, at page 112 of the decision, and basically says no access unless you can show that there are no alternative means of communication that exist, to simplify what it says there. Doesn't Babcock reflect a constitutional line-drawing that controls this case?

context.speaker: Michael J. Mongan
context.text: Well, Your Honor, I -- I agree that although it was a statutory case, the Court was recognizing the need to balance between property rights and the rights of employees to get this information. context.speaker: Brett M. Kavanaugh
context.text: But isn't that the problem right there? It took a different approach that intruded on -- on the property rights more than the Supreme Court, this Court, had allowed in Babcock? context.speaker: Brett M. Kavanaugh
context.text: It just went too far because it went beyond the NLRA?

context.speaker: Brett M. Kavanaugh
context.text: But the -- the flip side of that is Babcock's a problem for you because, if we just followed that and said that reflected the balance of the constitutional rights, the constitutional right here, you would lose under Babcock, I think.

context.text: Well, I don't think restraint means impediment, Mr. Chief Justice. I think it carries the definition from Direct Marketing.

CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.speaker: Justice Roberts

context.text: You offer several theories for why the text of the Anti-Injunction Act does not bar this suit. context.speaker: Cameron T. Norris
context.text: I think a suit like ours, Justice Alito, is barred when the taxpayer or the person subject to the notice has already violated the regulatory requirement such that tax penalties will imminently be assessed or they have been assessed already.

CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.speaker: Justice Roberts

context.text: It has to be an objective inquiry. And it has to be -- be able -- it has to be something a court can determine on the face of the complaint. And if you look at Direct Marketing, Bob Jones, and Regan, I think those cases point you to the questions that I raised, which are, what is being challenged, what are the injuries, and does the plaintiff have a refund suit? context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: All right.

context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: Cameron T. Norris
context.text: We disagree, Your Honor. context.speaker: Cameron T. Norris
context.text: There's no tax available for us to simply pay because our injuries are not tax liability.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Thank you, counsel.

context.speaker: Cameron T. Norris
context.text: That's our argument, Justice Kagan.

CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.speaker: Justice Kagan
CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.case_name: CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Service

context.speaker: Cameron T. Norris
context.text: Sometimes I -- I think the rigor that was present in Direct Marketing is missing from these cases, but I think Regan was correct that Congress never meant the Anti-Injunction Act to apply without a refund suit because those two provisions have always been side by side.

context.speaker: Cameron T. Norris
context.text: And that was the logic of that decision.

context.speaker: Cameron T. Norris
context.text: And we think that extends neatly to the situation where the government would require us to violate the tax code in order to trigger a refund.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And -- and -- and I guess this goes back to Justice Breyer's question, but it seems to me that your suit is different from Regan in two ways.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: One is that there was a constitutional claim there, and the second was that the Court kept on saying in Regan there's absolutely no alternative remedy available.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: It's not just a -- a favored alternative.

CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.speaker: Justice Roberts
CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.case_name: CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Service
CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 01, 2020

context.speaker: Cameron T. Norris
context.text: And I think, while South Carolina truly had no refund suit available, we are in the same situation in the sense that the only way we can get a refund is by committing a crime, risking imprisonment and massive fines, and violating our professional obligations as attorneys and accountants.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Norris.

context.speaker: Cameron T. Norris
context.text: So a refund is not available to us either.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Gorsuch.

context.text: Good morning, Mr. Norris.

context.text: I'd like to get your response or thoughts on Judge Sutton's concurrence in the denial of rehearing en banc, and he expressed one concern that, given the fact that the Anti-Injunction Act and Tax Injunction Act are so often interpreted in parallel, that by vindicating a taxpayer -- federal taxpayer's interests today, we might slight state sovereign concerns tomorrow, creating the risk that too much haste in stopping one abuse of power might open the door to another. I'd like your thoughts in response to that.

CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.speaker: Justice Roberts
CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.case_name: CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Service
CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 01, 2020

context.text: And it's -- it's worse than that because most of what the IRS does via regulation and guidance documents is enforced in some way by tax penalties.

context.speaker: Cameron T. Norris

context.text: Thank you.

context.text: Justice Kavanaugh.

context.text: So, Justice Kavanaugh, I think the way to cut through all of that is our South Carolina versus Regan argument, and I would just note that in the Florida Bankers case in the D.C. context.speaker: Cameron T. Norris
context.text: And --

context.speaker: Brett M. Kavanaugh
context.text: But isn't -- isn't that, as Justice Sotomayor pointed out, just a pleading exercise of how you frame it in your complaint? I'm challenging actually the regulatory part of the regulatory tax, as opposed to the enforcement of the liability itself?

context.speaker: Cameron T. Norris
context.text: I don't think so, Justice Kavanaugh.

context.speaker: Cameron T. Norris
context.text: I agree that a case involving a regulatory tax truly would be difficult.

CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.speaker: Justice Roberts

context.speaker: Cameron T. Norris
context.text: So that's how you know it is not just a tax.

context.speaker: Cameron T. Norris
context.text: Or it's not really a tax at all.

context.text: It is an independent regulatory requirement. context.text: I think the IRS's position is simple in that if any regulation is attached -- has a tax penalty attached, it triggers the Anti-Injunction Act, but that largely, as I said before, exempts the IRS from APA review. CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.speaker: Justice Roberts
CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.case_name: CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Service

context.speaker: Jonathan C. Bond

context.text: And we think that cuts strongly in our favor, that because Congress classified these as taxes, knowing that the elephant-in-the-room consequence is that they would be subject to the AIA, that Congress made the determination that the AIA should apply. context.speaker: Jonathan C. Bond
context.text: I do think --

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Thank you, counsel. Justice Thomas.

context.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice. Mr. Bond, the -- how would you define the word or the verb "to assess"?

context.speaker: Jonathan C. Bond

context.speaker: Jonathan C. Bond
context.text: First, Congress denominated it as a tax, and the point of a statutory definition like this is to say that something that is not ordinarily thought of to be a tax is to be treated as a tax. And I think the Court has for a century recognized that Congress can do exactly that.

context.speaker: Jonathan C. Bond
context.text: The Court rejected the argument that I think underlies that question in George 98 years ago, where -- where the point was: Look, the -- the argument was made: This is not really, in a child labor tax, an effort to raise revenue. This is really just an effort to penalize people engaged in certain child labor practices. And Chief Justice past opinion makes clear that doesn't change the outcome under the text of the Anti-Injunction Act.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Thank you, counsel. Justice Breyer.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Well, I think their point or a point is the Lincoln's point.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, calling something a tax doesn't make it one.

CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.speaker: Justice Roberts
CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.case_name: CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Service
CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 01, 2020

context.speaker: Jonathan C. Bond
context.text: First, if they are right that their conduct is, in fact, lawful because they disagree with us about that, then, when they get their judicial determination, the result will be that they never violated the law. Our view is different, and they run that risk.

context.speaker: Jonathan C. Bond
context.text: But, if they are right about the underlying merits, they will --

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So that's the answer to my question.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Thank you. Justice -- Justice Alito.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: The code says that willfully failing to comply with the reporting requirement is a crime.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: So I really don't see how they can get review without committing a crime.

CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.speaker: Justice Roberts

context.speaker: Jonathan C. Bond
context.text: And we're simply applying that consistent with what this Court has said is the appropriate avenue for a taxpayer to raise its challenges to requirements it believes are invalid. And I think it's not any -- any different from any taxpayer who believes that a particular tax, a substantive tax, is invalid if --

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: I -- I understand the position of the United States. Thank you.

context.text: Justice Sotomayor.

context.text: Counsel, in the normal situation, and I say normal, when I have to report something so that they can assess taxes against me, and I have a claim that I don't owe the tax, but you say I do, I pay the tax, I then can sue to say that I should have not had to pay the tax, how many laws are there like this one, disclosure laws where I wouldn't have to pay a tax, I only have to report certain information so that someone else can pay a tax? Do you have any idea how many laws there are like that?

context.speaker: Jonathan C. Bond
context.text: So I can't give you a precise number, but it's true that within the Internal Revenue Code there are a number of third-party or informational reporting requirements that -- that fit that description, and I think that that cuts strongly in our favor.

context.text: Counsel, in the normal situation, and I say normal, when I have to report something so that they can assess taxes against me, and I have a claim that I don't owe the tax, but you say I do, I pay the tax, I then can sue to say that I should have not had to pay the tax, how many laws are there like this one, disclosure laws where I wouldn't have to pay a tax, I only have to report certain information so that someone else can pay a tax? context.speaker: Jonathan C. Bond
context.text: So I can't give you a precise number, but it's true that within the Internal Revenue Code there are a number of third-party or informational reporting requirements that -- that fit that description, and I think that that cuts strongly in our favor.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: All right.

context.text: But could you hold on, counsel? context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Does that make any sense to you? They can never get that money back if they -- if they give you the information or if they don't give you the information.

context.speaker: Jonathan C. Bond
context.text: Well, here's the way I think the Court should look at it, Your Honor. I think it's no different fundamentally than any taxpayer who wants to engage in a particular transaction and wants to know in advance, would prefer to know before it undertakes the preparatory steps of the transaction or commits to the transaction, what the tax consequences will be.

CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.speaker: Justice Roberts
CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.case_name: CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Service

context.speaker: Jonathan C. Bond
context.text: Well, I'd say a couple of things.

context.speaker: Jonathan C. Bond
context.text: First, I don't think it's true that they have to pay some enormous penalty in order for this to happen for two reasons. First, they could choose to -- to follow the procedure outlined in Sullivan with respect to a single penalty and comply with respect to the rest, and they wouldn't face the tax penalty with respect to all of the other items. And, in addition, in our understanding, this penalty is what -- what's known in tax law as divisible, meaning that you can pay only a single part and then seek a refund over that and the government has to cross-claim for the rest.

context.speaker: Jonathan C. Bond
context.text: So it's not like they're immediately on the hook for massive liability the minute they choose to follow the procedure Congress outlined to obtain review. There are often --

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Kagan.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: The only problem is I'm not sure it really helps you here.

CIC Services, LLC v. Internal Revenue Se.speaker: Justice Roberts

context.text: I think it's really rational basis review; that is, if the FCC had decided to adopt an explicitly race- or gender-conscious standard, that is, give a preference to members of racial minorities or to women as such, then it would be required to satisfy heightened scrutiny, but it would be no --

context.text: There really -- we really are not talking in this case about regulation of the Internet or regulation of cable.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: I think the justification for enhanced regulation of the broadcast media has always been that the broadcast spectrum is scarce, not as many people can broadcast on the frequencies as would like to, and, therefore, it's necessary to have a federal agency that allocates the spectrum and decides how it can best be used to serve the public interest. context.text: Justice Breyer.

context.text: I'm thinking of it solely as a -- the anti-merger part, in -- in anti-merger law, merger law generally, I think, has a theory, and the theory is, beyond a certain point and other things being equal, you have fewer companies in a market, the harder it is to enter, and it's particularly harder for smaller firms.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And, here, smaller firms are heavily correlated or more likely to be correlated with women and minorities.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Alito.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Stewart, you said earlier that the Commission was not required by the statute to consider minority and female ownership, but the Commission did that.

context.text: That is, the deficiencies in the data don't result from the agency's current data collection practices. context.text: I -- I -- I think there are two things I would say about that. context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart

context.text: Thank you, counsel.

context.text: Justice Kagan.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: We were saying the evidence is fragmentary, but based on the evidence we have, our best assessment is there will not be a substantial effect. context.text: Under the statute and the public interest standard, does the FCC have to consider the effect of relaxing the rules on women and minority ownership?

context.speaker: Amy Coney Barrett
context.text: So you would be happy with a decision that said, you know, the -- the court -- the court of appeals can go outside of just what the jury saw, what was before the jury, and consider other record evidence like, for example, the PSR, and just not say anything about whether it's possible at step 4 in another case, in a non-Rehaif error case, for the court of appeals to go beyond that?

context.speaker: Benjamin W. Snyder
context.text: Yes, we'd be happy with a decision that said that.

context.speaker: Amy Coney Barrett
context.text: And then, just to go back to some of Justice Sotomayor's questions, do you agree in that circumstance, if the government could point to the PSR, that the defendant could cast doubt on the reliability of that evidence with things that may go outside of the record, like, for example, you know, mental capacity or other reasons why the defendant may not have known about it or maybe inaccuracies in the PSR?

context.speaker: Benjamin W. Snyder
context.text: Yes, we're -- we're fine with a decision that says that as well.

context.speaker: Amy Coney Barrett
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: Well, I would point you to the cardinal rule that provisions have to be construed in context and in light of their surrounding provisions.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: So, here, 113(f)(3)(B) is part of an integrated CERCLA contribution provision, and it makes sense to read the language, the key phrase "resolved its liability," and how that is used throughout the statute. And if you look at 113(f), it starts by establishing in (f)(1) the liability that -- that matters, and that's CERCLA liability.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: And then, in each provision thereafter, it uses the phrase "resolved its liability." And the government doesn't dispute that "resolved its liability" in (f)(2) means CERCLA liability, and there's no reason it would have any different meaning in (f)(3)(B). And I think that's perfectly consistent with the rule of context, that this always applies, and that the abnormal rule here is the one asserted by the government, which is that you should just take this provision and construe it as if it were an island in a vacuum without regard to its surround -- surrounding provisions.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Thomas.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice. Mr. Garre, is there any other instance in which -- that you can think of where the parties reach a settlement and then they turn around and sue each other over the very same problem?

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: Well, I mean, there -- there's certainly other instances that trigger a contribution claim, Your Honor, and -- and I think, you know, one of the incongruities here is that the -- the United States is not subject to suit under the Clean Water Act.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: We're not, Your Honor. We're -- we're -- we're bringing a cost recovery claim under Section 107(a) of CERCLA.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: The government's position is that we were required to bring a contribution claim in the wake of the Clean Water Act settlement. So it's really the -- the government's position that creates the anomaly there.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Breyer.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Thank you. If we got to the second question, I think your position is that a settlement requires -- for the purposes of this Act, it requires that there be an express admission of liability.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Why? I mean, people settle cases all the time where -- where they're not going to admit they were liable, but they might agree to take actions of X, Y, or Z in the future, and they might -- somebody might without -- do the same thing here.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I see.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Alito.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: I'd like to ask you a question about what you see as the relationship between Section 113(f)(1) and 113(f)(3). So 113(f)(1) provides contribution action to offset CERCLA liability and does so "during or following any civil action" under 106 or 107. Then paragraph 2 makes it clear that those who settle their liability won't be subject to a contribution action from the matters addressed in the settlement. And then what does 113(f)(3)(B) add? Aren't judicially approved settlements already covered by the phrase "following any civil action" in paragraph 1?

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: Well, I mean, I think what it does is it tells you that the -- the -- the federal -- the -- the CERCLA contribution claim is a federal claim, and so it would other -- override other provisions. And that's one of the problems that the state amici addressed and that the government's interpretation would mean that, anytime you settle a non-CERCLA claim under state law, it would trigger this federal contribution claim and, therefore, override states' different cost recovery regimes, which is a direct intrusion that this Court would not presume that Congress intended unless it said so. So I think the fact that Congress spelled out the contribution actions brought under federal law, you know, is quite significant in pointing to the conclusion that Congress didn't mean this strange contribution right the -- that the United States says it created.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Sotomayor.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Mr. Garre, I think it's your second question presented that may have created my colleague, Justice Breyer's confusion, because it was my own. Your question asks whether a settlement that expressly disclaims any liability determination and leaves the settling party exposed to future liability can trigger a contribution claim under CERCLA, Section 113(f)(3)(B). Settlement agreements often can disclaim liability but resolve liability at the same time.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Many settlement agreements will say, I don't admit liability, but I will resolve my liability under your claims under the Clean Water Act. That's what happened here, correct?

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Sotomayor.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Mr. Garre, I think it's your second question presented that may have created my colleague, Justice Breyer's confusion, because it was my own. Your question asks whether a settlement that expressly disclaims any liability determination and leaves the settling party exposed to future liability can trigger a contribution claim under CERCLA, Section 113(f)(3)(B). Settlement agreements often can disclaim liability but resolve liability at the same time.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Many settlement agreements will say, I don't admit liability, but I will resolve my liability under your claims under the Clean Water Act. That's what happened here, correct?

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: Well, yes and no.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: And it's inequity in that it --

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Counsel, please. Thank you.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Kagan.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Mr. Garre, I guess I -- I'm wondering whether your anchoring argument is -- is -- is really just an effort to make lemonade out of lemons, and -- and the reason I say that is because it's usually considered a problem in statutory interpretation when one provision, especially very close to another provision, has very different language. So, you know, (f)(1) says liability under 9607 or 9606.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And then (f)(3)(B) does not say that but instead uses a very different formulation, drops the section numbers, and says liability for some or all of a response action. So isn't the kind of obvious argument here that (f)(3)(B) meant something different from (f)(1)?

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: And that rule itself requires the conclusion that Congress meant the obvious, which is --

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Garre.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Gorsuch.

context.speaker: Neil Gorsuch
context.text: Mr. Garre, just to be clear, the -- there's no need for this Court to touch the 107 question, is there?

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: Well, no, Your Honor, there's not.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: I mean, ordinarily, you would try -- you would require a common liability, so you would settle liability for this, and you'd have a contribution claim under the same liability. And what the government's interpretation does here is to import this, you know, discrete CERCLA contribution claim as -- you know, into other federal statutes and to override other state laws that deal with cost contribution. I mean, Congress ordinarily doesn't create a contribution right, but, under the government's interpretation, the settlement of a claim other than CERCLA would trigger this contribution right under CERCLA and effectively import a contribution regime into other provisions, under federal law, as well as state law. And that's very disruptive, and it's hard to believe that Congress intended it.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: And all of those problems are resolved by giving this contribution provision its, you know, normal meaning of requiring the resolution of a common liability, which here would be CERCLA liability.

context.speaker: Neil Gorsuch
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Kavanaugh.

context.speaker: Brett M. Kavanaugh
context.text: Thank you, Chief Justice. And good afternoon, Mr. Garre.

context.speaker: Brett M. Kavanaugh
context.text: Do you -- or can you give me problems that you think would result outside of this case if we adopted the government's interpretation?

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: So -- so -- so that in itself is a -- is a problem that I think you would avoid unless Congress was clear. Another problem is, you know, the problem with displacing contrary federal -- federal and state cost recovery regimes, which I was discussing with Justice Gorsuch.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: I mean, I think it also creates this unprecedented contribution right, not known to the common law, where you don't need a common liability where the resolution of liability under one statute somehow triggers contribution right under a different statute. I mean, all of that is problems that this Court can void by simply construing this CERCLA contribution provision to be tied to CERCLA liability.

context.speaker: Brett M. Kavanaugh
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Garre.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Barrett.

context.speaker: Amy Coney Barrett
context.text: Good afternoon, Mr. Garre.

context.speaker: Amy Coney Barrett
context.text: I have a question just about how -- and I'm sure this comes of my ignorance of CERCLA actions -- but how this works. So 113(f)(3)(B) refers to response action, you know, which is defined in, you know, 106 and 107, which talks about the ability of -- you know, the -- the section that you want to sue the United States under, your ability to recover action -- cost of an action. So, if there's not been an action, so there's been no judicially determined amount of response costs and there's been no administrative or judicially approved settlement, how does the court go about or -- or how do the parties go about deciding whether costs undertaken actually were response costs?

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: I agree, Mr. Chief Justice. What that proves is that the presumption that the disparate inclusion and omission of language suggests a difference in meaning is not absolute.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: It can be overcome by competing indications in the opposite direction.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: And we do think there are competing indications in (f)(2), but there aren't in (f)(3)(B).

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Thank you, counsel. Justice Thomas.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice. Counsel, I'm -- I admit to being somewhat confused by this, primarily because of the earlier Clean Water Act settlement. Do you think that you could have a CERCLA recovery for, say, penalties under other environmental provisions?

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: No, Justice Thomas.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: They're on page 166a of the Petition Appendix, paragraphs 45, 46, and 48. Paragraph 45 says that the settlement settled the claims in the decree.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: And under the background law of preclusion and judgments, two claims are considered the same if they arise out of the same transaction or occurrence, even if they involve different statutes. This is confirmed by paragraph 46, which says that the decree should not be interpreted to limit the United States' right to bring claims involving unrelated violations. That necessarily implies that the decree does limit the United States' right to bring claims for related violations. There's also Justice Breyer's point that he raised in a question, which is the decree simply wouldn't make any sense if Guam didn't get anything out of it. Now they're relying on paragraph 48, but the first words of paragraph 48 are "except as specifically provided herein." And as I just explained, the decree does specifically provide herein for the elimination of the United States' right to bring related claims.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Breyer.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Well, the trouble I'm having on your side is I can't get too far using the language of the statute.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, sure, you could read it your way, "response action" refers to a -- any action, state or federal, brought under any statute dealing with a response action, which is defined in 23, 24.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: The Court made that point just last term in the Atlantic Richfield opinion when it said not everything under the sun qualifies as a response action. The second answer is that a lot of these cases involve sophisticated parties: governmental entities, territorial or state governments, and large corporations.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: These are the kinds of entities that can be expected to have good legal advice about how environmental laws interact with CERCLA. Finally, to the extent that there are case-by-case fairness problems, those should be addressed under a framework such as equitable tolling, not by distorting the meaning of the substantive statute itself.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Alito.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Counsel, Guam's argument in very simple terms is basically this: We're a small island, and the only reason -- and while we may have contributed to part of the problem with this dump, the Navy contributed quite a bit too.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: But, in any event, all of this -- the respective liability of Guam and the United States should be adjudicated under CERCLA, where the United States could bear some of the costs.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: It makes sense that Congress would provide a broader contribution right for settling parties than for non-settling parties.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Thank you. Thank you.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Sotomayor.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Counsel, I believe I'm right, because I've been told this in the briefing, that the word "responsive action" is not used in any other statute, am I correct --

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: But our position --

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Now, counsel, you know, one could be prompted to bid -- build a lid for a dump in response to CERCLA or one might do so in response to a nuisance claim in state court.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Both would be response actions. Why shouldn't it matter why a person initiates an activity? It -- it seems to me, just for the reasons Justice Alito just said, the simplest reason, if "response action" is CERCLA-specific in terms of all of the activities that can be, why should we build that into a different act, like the Clean Water Act? By the way, I thought that the harm addressed in the Clean Water Act was re-loosing -- releasing pollutants without a permit. That's a very different harm than what CERCLA looks to, which is releasing hazardous pollutants, with or without a permit, you're still prohibited from doing that. So those -- aren't those two different harms, and why should one extinguish or create an obligation to claim under another?

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: To take the first question first, the best answer is the list of provisions we've provided at pages 13 to 14 of our brief. These are provisions that show that CERCLA uses the word "response" to refer to actions taken under other statutes, including the Clean Water Act itself.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: This is on page 14, Section 9604(k)(12). Now, as for your question about the harms, we don't agree with the characterization that these harms are fundamentally different. EPA itself determined when deciding not to proceed under the -- under CERCLA that the Clean Water Act remedy would address both the CERCLA harm and the Clean Water Act harm.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: Certainly.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: But that's not what the statute requires.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Thank you, counsel.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Kagan.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Mr. Suri, I just wanted to make sure I understood your answer to the Chief Justice about the meaning of (f)(2). If I understood you right, you acknowledge that there was a gap in (f)(2), in other words, liability for what.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And you said that the way that gap should be filled is to say liability for a response action.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: It might be administratively easier, therefore, to focus the contribution inquiry on that rather than the section under which it arose. And the final reason is that (f)(1) was written by the House Energy and Commerce Committee and (f)(3)(B) was written by the House Judiciary Committee.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: They may have simply had different ideas about how this provision should operate.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Suri.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Gorsuch.

context.speaker: Neil Gorsuch
context.text: Good morning.

context.speaker: Neil Gorsuch
context.text: I'd like to ask you a question about preemption.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: There's no preemption there because they're both avenues that are open to those parties. Now it's true a party could choose to bring a federal contribution claim with respect to a state law liability under our interpretation, but that doesn't preempt the state.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: That just means that there are two options open to the settling party.

context.speaker: Neil Gorsuch
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Kavanaugh.

context.speaker: Brett M. Kavanaugh
context.text: Thank you, Chief Justice. Good afternoon, Mr. Suri.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: Good afternoon.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Kavanaugh.

context.speaker: Brett M. Kavanaugh
context.text: Thank you, Chief Justice. Good afternoon, Mr. Suri.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: Good afternoon.

context.speaker: Brett M. Kavanaugh
context.text: I think you said earlier that if Congress wanted to limit 113(f)(3)(B) to CERCLA, it could have said so. And, obviously, as is often the case, you could flip that question around and say if they wanted to -- if Congress wanted to usher in your position, they could have said so. So, in thinking about that framing of what's more likely here, what do you make of your opposing counsel's suggestion that you're cutting off a right to sue here, that there's a lack of fair notice, trap for the unwary? And I think that picks up also on some of Justice Breyer's questions.

context.speaker: Brett M. Kavanaugh
context.text: In other words, in thinking about how to think about what you're characterizing as silence here, let's just assume for the second that it -- that it is -- we should think about that consideration and how to interpret that here?

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: Justice Kavanaugh, there won't be a trap for the unwary going forward because the rule established by this Court will apply across the country and everyone will know what they have to do.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: -- statutory silence, if a provision is silent, the normal rule is to apply it according to its terms and not to infer an unstated limitation.

context.speaker: Vivek Suri
context.text: So, if you think the textual arguments are in equipoise, you should go with what the most natural reading of the term "response action" is, and that doesn't include any qualifiers such as "under CERCLA."

context.speaker: Brett M. Kavanaugh
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Suri.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Barrett.

context.speaker: Amy Coney Barrett
context.text: I have no questions.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: A minute to wrap up, Mr. Suri.

context.text: It's the question of who decides.

context.speaker: Kannon K. Shanmugam

context.speaker: Kannon K. Shanmugam
context.text: It's that the presumption of arbitrability should apply, and the court of appeals erred by failing to apply it here as a matter of federal law.

context.text: That's quite common in agreements between sophisticated commercial parties like the parties here.

context.text: Sure.

context.speaker: Kannon K. Shanmugam
context.text: Then, of course --

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Very brief -- briefly, counsel.

context.speaker: Kannon K. Shanmugam
context.text: If you don't have a delegation, then, of course, it's a question for the court to decide.

context.text: Justice Alito.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Oh, what do you understand to be the basis for the presumption of arbitrability? It was recognized, I think, the first time in Moses Cohen, and the Court said that it was based on the federal policy favoring arbitration, and it cited Section 2 of the Federal Arbitration Act. But the Federal Arbitration, Section 2, we have also said, requires equal treatment of arbitration contracts and other contracts. So what -- what is the basis for saying that there is this federal policy that produces the presumption that you rely on?

context.speaker: Kannon K. Shanmugam
context.text: It's a good question, Justice Alito, and I'm not sure that the Court has ever spoken to it, so let me offer a potential explanation. As you rightly point out, this Court has repeatedly said that Section 2 of the Arbitration Act, along with other sections, establishes the principle that arbitration agreements should be enforced according to their terms. But I think this Court has also recognized the presumption in favor of arbitration as flowing from the policy underlying the Arbitration Act as a whole. And that presumption, in turn, to pick up where Justice Breyer left off, seems to come from the labor context, where, of course, under federal law, you have the -- the Labor Arbitration Act, and you have in that Act, in the NLRA, a -- a -- a recognition that federal courts can recognize federal common law. So I think, if I were pressed, I would say it's probably ultimately a matter of federal common law, but it also appears to flow from the terms in the -- and -- and the structure of the statutes themselves.
